meanings.definition: Make (something) ineffective by applying an opposite force or effect.
meanings.sent1: She tried to neutralise the bad smell with a scented candle.
meanings.sent2: The superhero used his powers to neutralise the villain's attacks.
meanings.sent3: The cat's attempt to neutralise the mouse's escape plan was unsuccessful.
meanings.sent4: His apology helped neutralise the tension in the room.
meanings.sent5: The medicine worked to neutralise the poison in his system.

meanings.definition: Make (someone) unable to act in a particular way.
meanings.sent1: The magician used a spell to neutralise the audience's ability to speak.
meanings.sent2: The handcuffs were designed to neutralise the prisoner's movements.
meanings.sent3: The teacher's surprise test neutralised the students' plans to skip class.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness neutralised his anger and softened his heart.
meanings.sent5: The security system was set up to neutralise any unauthorized access.

meanings.sent1: Adding a base can neutralise the acidity of the solution.
meanings.sent2: The scientist neutralised the solution to achieve a pH of 7.
meanings.sent3: The chef accidentally neutralised the sauce, making it taste bland.
meanings.sent4: Her calm demeanor helped neutralise the tension in the room.
meanings.sent5: The antacid tablets can neutralise stomach acid and provide relief.
